category.description: A term for categorisations of pieces of art based on common themes, styles, plots, or explored concepts (e.g. horror, romance, fantasy)
category.name: Genre

category.description: An attitude or emotion communicated by a piece of art (e.g. dark, wholesome, comedy)
category.name: Tone

category.description: A concept or idea explored or represented in a piece of art (e.g. romance, dystopia, death, love)
category.name: Theme

category.description: A format by which a piece of art is presented (e.g. Television, Film, Theatre, Short story)
category.name: Medium

category.description: An environment within which a story or piece of art is presented (e.g. western, space, steampunk)
category.name: Setting

category.description: A span of time (usually specific to a single culture or collection of cultures) during which a piece of art was created (e.g. 1930s, 19th century, Ancient Rome)
category.name: Period (Created)

category.description: A span of time (usually specific to a single culture or collection of cultures) during which events within a piece of art take place (e.g. Ancient Rome, near-future, viet-nam war)
category.name: Period (Setting)

category.description: An author, designer, or creative voice involved in the production of a piece of art (e.g. Jane Austen, Ursula K. Le Guin, Kazuo Ishiguro)
category.name: Creator

category.description: A fictional story, often containing moralistic or cautionary lessons behind a fantasy adventure (e.g. Snow White, Little Mermaid, Alice in Wonderland)
category.name: Fairy Tale
